title: How to Check Server Uptime
content: To check server uptime, use the `uptime` command in Linux. This shows how long the system has been running, number of users, and load averages. Example output: `14:23:45 up 10 days, 3:14, 2 users, load average: 0.15, 0.20, 0.18`

title: Understanding Load Average
content: Load average represents the average system load over 1, 5, and 15 minutes. Values below the number of CPU cores indicate good performance. For a 4-core system, load average of 3.0 is acceptable, while 6.0 indicates system strain.

title: SSH Key-Based Authentication
content: SSH key authentication is more secure than passwords. Generate keys with `ssh-keygen -t rsa -b 4096`. Copy public key to server with `ssh-copy-id user@server`. Disable password authentication in `/etc/ssh/sshd_config` by setting `PasswordAuthentication no`.

title: MySQL Slow Query Analysis
content: Enable slow query log in MySQL to identify performance issues. Set `slow_query_log = 1` and `long_query_time = 2` in my.cnf. Analyze logs with `mysqldumpslow` to find queries taking over 2 seconds. Optimize with proper indexes and query restructuring.

title: Apache vs Nginx Performance
content: Apache uses process-based model, better for dynamic content. Nginx uses event-driven model, excels at static content and reverse proxy. For high-traffic sites, use Nginx as reverse proxy with Apache backend for best of both worlds.
